The new Star Trek series has brought the old characters into the mainstream and made them cool.  Many people see the old Star Trek as "nerdy" but this new interpretation makes the characters gritty and deep.  J.J. Abrams has used a combination of incredible special effects, witty dialogue, and pure action to bring Star Trek to "the next generation" (couldn't resist the pun).  This story picks up where the first one left off, developing the relationship between Kirk and Spock and again throwing Kirk into the center of controversy.  With the character origins established in the first installment, this film gets right into the action and allows for the introduction of Khan.  He is one of the most intriguing characters in the franchise and Benedict Cumberbatch is the perfect actor to deliver this sophisticated dialogue.   The plot twists back and forth, keeping you on your heels and trying to figure out if Khan is helpful or dangerous.  The greatest part of the film is the heroism and sacrifice displayed at the end.  It really gets to the heart of science fiction and superhero movies of days past.  Whoever dreamed up this script should be commended for successfully bringing Khan back to life (pun intended), building chemistry between Spock and Kirk, echoing the themes set forth in the opening of the film, resolving the seemingly impossible plot twist, and setting up the next film with the "Space: the final frontier" speech.  This greatly exceeds the expectations of most action movies.  All of the acting is spot on and I love how they found a way to feature Simon Pegg as Scotty, even though he wasn't critical to the themes being developed throughout the film.  Space has come to life with "Star Trek: Into Darkness."  Not only am I anxious for the next installment, but I may even have to go back and watch the original films.

Sort of a long-winded predecessor to the 2009 reboot. I can't decide if Into Darkness is objectively worse than Star Trek, but I definitely responded more favorably to Star Trek. Perhaps because going into Star Trek I had zero expectations, thus ended up fairly pleasantly surprised. Here I was expecting a lot more and ended up kind of let down. It's a fine sort of movie, but it has a number of warts that I'm having trouble getting past.

1. Karl Urban. His attempt at acting here is befuddling for how much it is like watching someone parody the character on YouTube. Heck, an untalented, never-before-acted parody would probably deliver more subtlety and texture to the character than Urban provides. I had to do that combination cringe-lol every time he was on screen.

2. The convoluted plot is too hard to follow. In a movie like this where there is a strong villain, we don't need a deep intricate plot. Deep plots are fine... as long as they can be followed amid all the chaos. However, best to lose some of that complexity in cases like this where the plot points are likely to get lost amid explosions and lens flares. It's not so much about WHAT is going on on-screen, but trying to figure out the reasons WHY that becomes problematic.

3. Trying to give Spock too much emotion. Ok, perhaps the original series went a bit too far in de-emotionizing Spock. Then again, a part of the draw of the character were the few slight times that he allowed his human side to show. Here he's practically a bundle of emotions. This is a case where perhaps Into Darkness succeeds at factually portraying a 50% Vulcan, 50% human combo, but it results in a character that is a far cry from what makes the original Spock so endearing.

4. Speaking of Spock, the Leonard Nemoy cameo feels horrifically shoehorned in and unnecessary. What we need at the end of movie 2 in this reboot series is for young Spock to take things by the reins and prove that He Is Spock. Calling up Old Spock for a spot of instruction hardly inspires confidence.

So Into Darkness still manages to be fun, but it's in that grey area of being kind of a bad movie all at the same time. Hard to hate, hard to love.

Star Trek Into Darkness attempts a "Dark Knight" Of the franchise and although hits a lot of the right marks, its predictability and lack of confidence to see things through, hold it off from being a monumental film, however it does enjoy a phenominal action packed success. Almost tripling the action and set piece from the series reboot in 2009, JJ Abrams boldly attempts to get our pulse racing from the very beginning with a gorgeous and heart racing opening. The character art and location is visually unique and stunning, using CGI to push the vibrancy of a doomed planet and its occupants. This will continue throughout the film, however a mixed bag of irritating lens flare and trying to keep this too family a film, almost does it a disservice. The story begins as Kirk, played amazingly by Pine, and his team are forced to save Spock, yet again amazingly played by Quinto, as he decides to save a species from extinction. This is obviously against protocol and upon completion of the mission and successful return to earth, Kirk is pulled from his captaincy of the USS Enterprise for recklessness and lack of rule following. Felt betrayed by Spock, Kirk goes off the radar and all the while, John Williamson, Yet again a extraordinary performance from Benedict Cumberbatch, uses the will of a dying daughters father to commit sabbotage against an archive facility in London. Thus leading to all the leading members of the star fleet to meet in the one location. This predictably is where John wants them and after slaughtering Pike and other heads of the enterprise, John hides out on a Klingon planet as refuge and Kirk and his team are ordered to head to this "Uninhabited" planet in order to nuke John from orbit. It is all naturally a bit fishy and before you know it all hell has broken loose and of course, John isnt quite who we thought he was and offers Kirk and his crew quite possibly the worst threat they could encounter... Sorry the film would let you believe it is going to do that, however the outcome is one thats bark is much worse than its bite. Firstly the cast is just jaw dropping, talent from Urban, Pegg, Pine, Quinto, Salander, Cumberbatch and Yelchin are all top notch. Playing the characters expertly, paying homage from whence they came, however not parodying it. Its a tough call but JJ ensures its execution perfectly. In fact you genuinly love every character you encounter, apart from Benedict but thats because hes doing his job properly. The CGI is extremely impressive for its time and for the most part does an excellent job of not becoming to irritating... Apart from that trademark JJ lens flare, it pains me to say it but its close to crippling at points, there is no need for that effect every 3 shots. It brings you completely out of the experience and from what i could tell, only hightens one if not maybe two effects on the grand scheme of things. Luckily the DOP does some stunning and imaginitive work in order to keep our eyes invested beyond the CGI and the mix of sets and green screen is a welcome one, after such films which shall not be names decide to use entirely green screen. Michael Giacchinos score is pounding and accompanies these visuals wonderfully, never is there a dull moment in this film and the music only services to ensure this is the case. Now where the films biggest flaws lay and no its not the lens flare, come from its predictability and its lack of "Cahoanies" without giving too much away, Cumberbatch plays a massive villainous role within this film, and to be honest from the get go, we can see the twist coming. Much like we can  see the outcome of many things coming in this film. the script and director feel the need to spell things out every 15 minutes or so, just incase you as a viewer decide that over the length of two hours is too much to hold your attention for... The amount of times i was narrating in my head what was going to happen next was unbearable and even in some cases, quoting lines i hadnt heard yet. This is not good, had this been any less of a film it would be a catastrophy, luckily it has its eye set on spectical and character that its gaping obviousness is allowed through. It's second fault is that Into Darkness, clearly highlighted by its title, wants to get get gritty and dark and visceral. Good, so why then do i feel like im watching a tamed down version? Why doesnt the director or the writers actually put us in a position where there is no going back? Why does the "Wrath" of a certain character, actually just end up as a bunch of CGI destruction and a small "tear jerking" moment that enduces no tears because for the past few hours it has spelt out the ending for you? I know that not all films need to be pitch black to be perfect, however it feels here that JJ wanted something a lot darker than he submits for our viewing pleasure. Thus making it fall short of "Dark Knight" stature. All that aside though, as a action block buster, it is without a doubt bombastic and a film where you actually give a rats ass about the characters. Enjoyable, fun and fast paced, let down only by not doing as it promised, taking us truely "Into" the "Darkness"

This film is a disgrace to the Star Trek franchise. This film is practically blasphemous, because The Wrath of Khan was the best Star Trek film of all time, and this film screwed it all up. First off, the fact that the Romulans and THE Spock went back in time 154 years does not effect Khan Noonien Singh in any way, so he should still be of Indian ethnicity. This is, quite simply put, A HUGE CONTINUITY PROBLEM. Not only that, but one of the best (and most saddening) moments in all of science-fiction was when Spock sacrificed his life for the crew of the Enterprise at the end of The Wrath of Khan. Now, the lines "The needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few, or the one." and "I have been -and always shall be- your friend." have been desecrated. Even though this doesn't introduce a continuity problem like the change of Khan's ethnicity, this just destroys everything that was meaningful in the ending events of The Wrath of Khan. Not only that, but it leaves out the Genesis Project all together, which basically does away with all the events of The Search For Spock and The Voyage Home. I'm done with JJ Abrams, and quite frankly I think it was a mistake to hire him as director for the upcoming Star Wars film. Mark my words, he will destroy yet another series!

Abrams is back with a sequel/prequel to his snazzy, new Star Trek vision. The focus is supposed to be upon making the characters as much like the originals as possible, and I am very fond of the casting choices. Zachary Quinto was born to play the part of Spock, and Chris Pine is a very fine Kirk. Who could not approve of Simon Pegg in the role of Scotty? The comic relief he provides is perfectly timed and essential to the film's flow. I loved seeing Cumberbatch at his villain-esque best as well. The only acting choice I did not agree with was John Cho as Sulu. He's just completely wrong for the part.

I enjoyed the film just as much as I did the first Abrams installment. There is plenty of action for those who crave explosions, but the characters remain the nuts and bolts of the story. It's still difficult for me to get my head around the whole Spock and Uhura thing. I was raised on the old tv programs, and I remember how Spock could never really commit himself to a relationship. I understand that Abrams' ideal for Spock is someone who can be both innately logical as well as loving, but it deviates a bit too much for me, and I found it a bit distracting. Perhaps an unrequited affection on Uhura's part would have suited me better.

All in all, I believe that most Trekkies would be pleased with the outcome; and even those of us who just walk the fringe of that circle can come away satisfyingly entertained. Abrams is undoubtedly pleased by its success.

From the outset, I didn't find the movie that great.  This was due to the irritating characters.  Didn't like Captain Kirk (or at least Chris Pine's marverick portrayal of him) in the first movie, and that didn't change here.  Scotty was just so cliched, and the constant whining in a fake Scottish accent was annoying.  Doctor McCoy was the worst of the lot: even more whiny than Scotty, and everything he said was so cheesy.  Every line of Dr McCoy's dialogue had me rolling my eyes.

Didn't mind Spock, Sulu or Chekov though.

Initially, it looked like the plot might pull the movie through.  Was intriguing.  However, from a point, it takes a bizarre and nonsensical turn.  Kirk basically sides with a terrorist against his own fleet.  Its as if JJ Abrams was trying to make a political statement, and a very misguided one.

After that the plot is pretty random, and the movie never recovers.

Star Trek Into Darkness is contender for best film of 2013. I've got a few favourites this year: Gangster Squad, Oblivion and Hansel and Gretel Witch Hunters, and now Into Darkness is in my top favourites. I've never felt so immersed and involved in a sci-fi movie this much since last year's Total Recall, every location in space and on futuristic Earth looks real and each part of the Enterprise is convincing. The beautiful 3D gets you in on the action even more as every object shoots out at you with ferocity, the depth effects are astounding as locations disappear into the background and flakes of dust and sparks hover off the screen, this is the most active and alive 3D of the year! Chris Pine's performance is brilliant as Kirk, I once thought he was a typical actor who only did silly rom coms but damn he's good, he proves he can act in a diverse range of movies. Kirk still disobeys the rules and his ignorance costs him dearly, this is true character development, same goes to the rest of the cast who are equally gripping to watch, and best of all it's great to see every cast member get it on the action, and Saldana is back and better than before. Benedict Cumberbatch is fierce and merciless, his deep bass filled voice echoes sending chills down your spine as he utters every piece of dialogue, "I will walk over your cold corpses, and then I will recover my crew. . .Now, shall we begin?" I love the story, which constantly unfolds across different planets and then ends up with one of the best action packed finales since Transformers Dark of The Moon, where the Vengeance obliterates downtown San Francisco, then Khan and Spock battle it out on a hover-jet, the special effects here are utterly jaw dropping. I find this sequel far more entertaining than the first movie, don't get me wrong the first is truly amazing, but Into Darkness lives up to it's sinister title delivering moments of shocking tension and brutality alongside blistering action in stunning 3D.

A dull, thoughtless and pointless re-imagining of Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan. JJ Abrams must think that seeing the exact same scenarios played again will make fans cheer, but instead bores and offends, like a drunken, idiot karaoke singer butchering a classic song. The acting talent and hardship is hard to decipher, what with a script full of inconsistencies and erratic melodrama that spawns, literally, out of the disease-infected arse of the screenwriters (amazed that I just witnessed an entire team effort at stupidity). However, Mr. Cumberpatch is quite interesting to watch: the tighter he smushes his face, the more his eyes leak, as if his head was being juiced whenever he speaks about "his crew," then goes back to resuming his boring monotone that he is most celebrated for. His jaw-opening ability is showcased with every vowel he utters, proving that he could literally swallow an entire jelly donut whole. It is, without argument, the most unique and interesting aspect of the film. Though Abrams' inability to convey any rational thought or emotion of his characters , his no-talent is further reflected by his inability to comprehend the blatant logical fallacies within the script. A great film for the "average" moviegoer with an "average" 100 IQ, though I've seen better looking film on teeth.

***This review contains spoilers***

It's been said before, but I'll say it again:

-Khan's big plan to save his crew involved hiding them in TORPEDOES. That's right, he planned to save his friends by inserting them into DEADLY WEAPONS.

-Kirk is given 72 torpedoes to kill ONE MAN. One man on a planet's surface, no less. Khan wasn't even in a starship. He's ordered to fire them all. Sure, we find out that these torpedoes have supermen in them, and that admiral Marcus wants them dead, but Kirk doesn't even QUESTION the order.

-Why was the Enterprise underwater at the film's start, and how did it get there initially without being seen by the planet's natives?

-Kirk, again and again, displays a disregard for authority and an affinity for bad decisions. Furthermore, he NEVER EVEN GRADUATED FROM STARFLEET ACADEMY! Why does he get to command the Federation's flagship?

-Khan beamed from Earth to Kronos. If such transporter technology exists, why bother with starships at all?

-An injection of Khan's blood will CURE DEATH. Essentially, humanity no longer needs doctors. How are we going to fear for our favorite characters' lives in the next movie? Also, Kirk was dead for all of 15 minutes. His death had almost no emotional impact.

-Where were the rest of Earth's forces during the final confrontation in Earth's atmosphere? Nobody even thought to HAIL the ships and see what was up? Did nobody in Starfleet notice the big space battle?

And I've only scratched the surface here.

It wasn't the action. It wasn't the acting. It wasn't the references to previous films. It certainly wasn't a reaction against the film's popularity. It was the plot holes. The film was riddled with them. I walked out of the theater thoroughly unsatisfied. I'm surprised that so many people reacted so positively to this film, and am glad to see that at least the diehard fans have some sense, even if the rest of the moviegoing public was content to swallow such a flimsy plot.

I am a fan of Star Trek and sci fi in general, this lush film explores the complicated relationships between these familiar characters.  JJ Abrams rebootted Star Trek, a sort of "parallel universe" concept that really freed him to play with the Star Trek mythos. In Star Trek Into Darkness (an interesting title) we see some darkness with a  recurring theme of "who do you trust?"  As the film begins we see the differences in our main characters Kirk and Spock.  Spock is a by the book regulations following noble intelligent good guy.  Kirk relies on wits and charisma, he flies by the seat of his pants and has an extra ration of luck on his side, but he feels that one can bend the rules to do what is morally right.  This sets up tension that lasts throughout the film.  A villain John Harrison attacks Starfleet and the crew of the Enterprise are sent on a mission to kill him.  That is the basic plot.  But we find circumstances arrive that put into question who to trust.  The Darkness the title suggests is some ambiguous moral darkness.  Overall this is an exciting and well written and performed movie.  Get the popcorn out and enjoy.

This second film with the new cast almost captures the panache of the first - in the final 10 minutes.  Before that, it feels partly like a rehash (telling us again what we learned in the first film) and partly like any sci-fi actioner, CGI crash-bang shoot-em-up.  And yes, Benedict Cumberbatch IS everywhere (this time as the villain, Khan - yes, THAT Khan).  What is really lacking here is a plot - what little story offered to us is only wafer thin.  The human relationships are schematic, held together by scenes of predictable emotion (or lack of emotion, when it comes to Spock).  But the two hours passed easily and I didn't feel too guilty for squandering them.  When the zesty feel of the old serials appeared near the end, I almost thought I might invest time in the next one, because undoubtedly there will be one.  But it could be just another genre film going through the motions.

For a franchise built on "going where no man has gone before," everything in "Star Trek Into Darkness" feels incredibly run-of-the-mill. The plot makes zero sense, character motivations are imperceptible, and Kirk simply repeats the same character arc he had in the first film, leaving the entire affair to cruise purely on pretty visuals and cast chemistry. Granted, this was the main draw of the first film too, but things felt far more balanced the first go around (Uhura's role is now "nagging girlfriend;" Sulu, Bones, and Chekhov barely register; and Alice Eve's Carol appears for nothing more than a few moments of blatant objectification). Qunto and Pegg are maybe the only two cast members to come through unscathed, while Chris Pine is embarrassingly awful at times.

Benedict Cumberbatch's villain is entertaining in spurts, but he's also all over the map and plays a variety of functions-- part tactical genius, part tortured anti-hero, part Bourne-esque superspy, part sociopathic terrorist-- yet he never fully inhabits any of these roles, and never makes much of an impact as a result.  The decision to name him "Khan"-- a classic Trek villain with which he shares zero characteristics-- was downright baffling, and keeping it a secret from the public by way of the "John Harrison" moniker (despite no narrative consequence whatsoever) was even more bizarre. Using his character to preach 9/11 truther conspiracy stuff (and inject some supposed political relevancy by ripping off "The Dark Knight") come across as ham-fisted and dumb.

The lack of dramatic stakes in the final twenty minutes are utterly laughable (Bones desperately needs the blood of a genetic super-being like Khan to revive Kirk! There's like fifty of them in the room he's standing in!), but I appreciated that an FX heavy blockbuster would feature a relatively low-key foot-chase as its climactic action sequence (Sometimes bigger isn't better). It's a profoundly uneven film that occasionally stumbles upon some good moments and ideas, but it can't draw them together in a remotely satisfying way. There's less lens flare though, so that's something.

4 years after the reboot of the popular franchise directed by J.J Abrams has now returned with a sequel. Star Trek Into Darkness is definitely a much anticipated sequel due to the first film being successful commercially and critically. Hype is inevitable with films like these, which at times is a good thing but that very same thing can be the cause of the film's demise, due to the increase in expectations and ambition. This sequel have been argued whether or not this is an improvement over it's predecessor, but there is one thing I can guarantee and is that this film is definitely a well made Science Fiction Action film.

Star Trek Into Darkness was written by Alex Kurtzman, Damon Lindelof & Roberto Orci, and all three acts as screenwriters and producers of this film and it's predecessor. Kurtzman and Orci have shown their weaknesses in films like the Transformers series but both have definitely made up for those films with their contribution to the Star Trek franchise. Lindelof has collaborated with Abrams frequently, and the one out of the three writers for this film that has written some films with great stories (Prometheus & World War Z), at least in my opinion. The sequels of the franchise is usually the best opportunity for the writers to dish out the best stories for the franchise as they are not restricted in having to explain the characters back stories and having to define the relationship between characters. Star Trek Into Darkness can truly be a film of it's own. You don't need to watch the first one to fully understand this film as it doesn't rely solely on the previous film to drive the plot. The writers have definitely written something I found enjoyable with a plot that is intriguing and a villain that is so mesmerizing to watch that we wouldn't mind if the film focused on him even more. The film's screenplay is definitely thematically deeper than the first film. The film explores themes of friendship, death, sacrifice, and family. This did impress me in comparison to other blockbuster films released this year and it's something that I will definitely come back to over and over again and it would still not lose it's steam. The film also does some throwback moments to previous Star Trek films which will surprise the fans of the franchise.

J. J. Abrams comes back to direct this sequel of his successful Star Trek reboot. Abrams have definitely crafted something much better than it's predecessor as this may be due to a much better understanding and connection to the source material. Abrams have crafted something that is different from the other Star Trek films released but able to relate and throwback elements from the classics. Abrams have made something deep and entertaining. It may not be as in your face and pretentious as other films that touches the same themes as it still retains it's action packed entertainment approach which I don't mind either as long as it is executed with flourish, and Abrams has executed with such flourish. Abrams were able to sneak in some still and heartbreaking moments that surprisingly made me care about the characters, which is something I usually dismiss in films like this. This does give me more faith with Abrams future films, as he has disappointed me before like Mission Impossible 3. I hope he does return for a sequel to this film as he definitely revived a franchise to a new generation and hopefully for future ones.

Daniel Mindel comes back as the director of photography for this film. Mindel is more known as an action director and he is a frequent collaborator with Abrams, aside from Super 8. Mindel and Abrams have brought back the beautiful photography that was present on the first film. The visual effects in this film do look impressive and improves the already fascinating effects from the first film. The lens flare in this film is much more toned down, or maybe it just seemed less distracting due to the improved technique in photographing this film. The shots that Abrams and Mindel uses for this film, especially within the ship, are filled with panning and this is due to the great blocking that Abrams employs in his shots allowing the film to be constantly in motion but without relying on the shaking effect of handheld camera. They also applied the same odd and disjointed angles that were abundant from the first film, but at least in here it feels less distracting. As the film does contain certain intimate moments, I felt that they were shot fantastically and adds on to the tension or emotion that Abrams wants to convey or bring out from us.

Michael Giacchino is responsible for the film's score. When the film's theme song plays, it gives me the chills as it just makes me think that we are coming into a special film. Giacchino has brought the good areas from his score of the first film and improved upon that with this film feeling much more ambitious and heavy. Though the moment at the start of the film with the sick child contains a beautiful piece driven by a piano. Giacchino definitely knows how to suck us in with his scores, just listen to his work on the Pixar films like Up and Ratatouille.

The actors in this film is more focused solely on their interaction with one another rather than a separate entity of it's own like the first film, due to the first film focusing on their backstory and how that connects to the way these characters are. I can definitely say that these actors work well together and more moments show their acting range. Pine and Quinto banter and acting, particularly in scenes where their relationship and feelings towards one another are being discussed and explored, have definitely grabbed on to me; making me care about the decisions of these characters and empathise with them. A stand out performance from Benedict Cumberbatch is definitely something that needs to be noted when praising this film. Great and scene stealing villains are not something unique in films nowadays but his is something that cannot be ignored. If I am to nitpick, I am still a little disappointed with Karl Urban's character being a source of one liners, the character is also written quite campy which does become a distraction for me. All in all the actors did a great job and hopefully the next film will allow more screentime to flesh out both the actors and the characters they play.

Star Trek Into Darkness is ambitious and thematically deeper than it's predecessor. It is also more entertaining and features a villain that we won't forget. I hope that Abrams come back for a third installment and somehow improve on a film that is definitely one of the best blockbuster films of 2013.

Ahh where to begin with this movie? It is everything that Star Trek isn't and prided itself in not being. I can't imagine a franchise taken in a more opposite of a direction from the source material. To me it seems like it cannot take from old material enough however doesn't try to implement it correctly or use it in the plot but just throws things in because they are recognizable to a general audience. Coming to a head for me when they shoehorn in Leonard Nimoy in again, and tell Spock how the movie is going to end. It is really insulting to the old series how muddled and half thought out these ideas are.

Whether you consider it a remake of "Wrath of Khan" or a spin-off set in an alternate reality, "Into Darkness" is a visually beautiful and well scripted movie.  Shatner and Nimoy left shoes that can likely never be truly filled, but JJ Abrams' first "Star Trek" proved that the great story of the USS Enterprise's fove-year journey could be retold appropriately and well for both an old and new audience.   My only mild critique is the puzzling reason why Benedict Cumberbatch was chosen to play the feralistic Khan, but Abrams' sleeker style to the series seems realistic enough for a futuristic universe to make up for this momentary head-scratcher. "Into Darkness" continues an engaing and interesting what-if story that will leave you as emotional and satisfied as the original "Wrath of Khan" did years ago.

Star Trek Into Darkness Review

When I think of Star Trek, I think of deep space exploration, Klingon encounters, science fiction inspired character design and those awesome shades that La Forge wears in Next Generation. Well, I'm proud to announce that the latest film in this everlasting and praised franchise, Star Trek Into Darkness, has those features (okay, maybe the shades are missing). The new film by director J.J. Abrams is a well-made, action packed and visually striking piece of work as many would expect from Abrams. Into Darkness boasts energetic performances by all actors and actresses, flashy cinematography and excellent set pieces. However, where it excels in visual and performance, it lacks in overall story or long term impact.
In terms of plotline, Into Darkness shows that it can compel just enough for the viewer to be interested. The film's biggest strength also turned out to be its contributor to its negatives. It is shrouded with action and epic visuals which tended to throw the story in the backseat while it could boast its high budget cost to "woo" the audience. I can't say I'm the biggest fan of this tactic the filmmakers go with, but many will really enjoy it as it has obviously shown in its box office success. I do not want to delve too far into the plot of the film, but it does successfully pull off some twists and turns that remain entertaining enough.
The negative of plotline aside, the film features some excellent performances from all actors and actresses with Benedict Cumberbatch as a personal favorite, playing the role of Khan. Somehow, this man seems to command the screen every time he shows up in a scene (probably because of that epic deep voice he's got). He's a force to be reckoned with and an actor that has a successful future ahead of him; maybe even Oscar worthy. Other noteworthy performances include Chris Pine, Zachary Quinto and Simon Pegg (as always), but I only wish that Zoe Saldana had a bit more screen time. I felt that her character was also a backup idea just to assist in exploring the relationship that she and Quinto's character, Spock, shared. This film new who it wanted to focus on and it did just that, however, I think that for Saldana and even John Cho's character, Sulu, should have had more say and more to do. I mean, surely Cho was upset that he didn't have any fight scenes like he did in the first film or he had wished he said more than three lines. Just a personal gripe...
Star Trek is one of the first blockbuster hits of the summer movie season (followed by Iron Man 3) and there are many more to come. Overall, it was a great film and will surely appeal to a fan base and those looking for a good time at the movies. But, these kinds of movies are just not doing it for me anymore. I mean, I prefer movies that grab me and pick at my brain. Now, I completely understand that this is not the goal of Star Trek or Iron Man intend to implement, but, for me, I'm looking for some different. They have an idea in mind and that is to simply entertain and in this case, it succeeded. This was a great movie, but it is one I'm already forgetting about. 
So, what do you guys think? I welcome criticism, not only about the film, but my overall review itself (I am no professional). Let me know your thoughts in the comments section below so we can discuss. Thanks guy and go watch movies!!

Much as I often think JJ Abrams directs films by numbers (lens flare, trademark angles etc), I do love his numbers. This is a right rollicking action movie with quite a lot of heart and a good deal of intelligence. It races from one sequence to another, with barely anytime for the audience to keep up, which serves to (a) make this quite an exhausting 2 hours and 11 minutes, and (b) cover over some of the plot holes that, once you have a few seconds to scrutinise them, are glaringly obvious...

All that said, there's a lot of great stuff here and it's fantastically entertaining. Zachary Quinto and Chris Pine develop their excellent chemistry and relationship as Spock and Kirk, and there seemed to be less of the annoying comedy accents of Scotty and Chekhov. I also liked the politicking with the senior Starfleet commanders. Best of all is Benedict Cumberbatch, who proves he can do beefcake supervillain as well as intellectial sociopath. He's brilliant and steals every scene he's in.

PLOT SPOILER and major complaint: the last sequence of the film involves a spaceship crashing through downtown San Francisco, demolishing countless skyscrapers and several square miles of city centre. After barely a few seconds to take in the  destruction we cut to 12 months later and almost nothing seems different. The city seems fine, noone mentions the tens of thousands who surely perished. Hmmm - a disappointing, flippant and rushed end to an otherwise terrific film.

Into Darkness does not fall short behind of 2009's reboot -- it's a big step-down, but it's still a success when it comes to entertainment.

The crew is back, with splendid characters and natural chemistry. Kirk is immature as always -- and some romance is continuously developing between Nyota and Spock. It's not the most character-driven film -- they seriously lack more development and inside. Antagonist does on the other hand deliver relatable motivations even if a more "want-to" to win against him would have made it an even greater film. Cumberbatch brought a big win! It's a more action-anger driven version of what we know Star Trek used to be -- with a mix of mystery, corruption & some "meh:s". Visuals & cinematography is a pure wonder yes, but it simply isn't that much of a "wow" -- with its less passionate story with fragments of convenient/illogical events & plot holes. The latest installment "Beyond" success over this when it comes to character depth -- this is however a better directed and got more focus on story. It's a popcorn-flick for the sci-fi/action fan -- that's for sure. But a "meh" ride for others.

Another great entry into JJ Abrams' Star Trek reboot. One of the funnest and tensest summer movie experience in 2013. Crisis after crisis compiles in this movie, making audience wonder when are they going to let the tension go? The answer, when the movie abruptly ends in a somewhat anticlimatic way.

Because the star trek tv franchise sets the bar so high in terms of production quality it sets an even higher bar for movies bearing its name. This film had its grin moments when for example you first heard the voice of scotty and the other recognisable voices from the past. I loved the opening sequence and the red forest and the characters that inhabited that world, I wish it had continued in that vein. When you strip it down this is a poor version of Good vs Evil placed in a Star Trek setting. One line summary: Abrams' Star Trek; perhaps not Roddenberry's.

------------------

    In this second Star Trek film of the Abrams era, Kirk and Spock are still running the Enterprise, and are still doing it in amateurish fashion.  However, there is a lot of action, excitement, and relief when difficulties are overcome.

    In completing the mission in the opening sequence, Kirk violates the prime directive in order to save Spock who was doing the last part of saving a new species of sentient beings.  Sigh.  Kirk loses command of the Enterprise.

    Admiral Pike finagles getting Kirk to be his First Officer just before there is an attack on a critical Star Fleet installation.  The attack leads to a high level conclave of Star Fleet officers.  Kirk figures this out just before the attack, and manages to blunt (but not stop) its effects.  There are heavy losses.  Kirk gets back the Enterprise, and is ordered to find and kill the perpetrator.  His crew is given special weapons to accomplish this.

    Kirk's quarry is traced to a deserted part of Kronos, the Klingon homeworld.  The quarry's real name is Khan who is the maximal result of a eugenics experiment done many years earlier on Earth.  Admiral Marcus (Pike's superior) had hoped to use Khan against an array of future enemies, such as the Klingons.  Khan and Marcus had a falling out, though, and the whole dynamics of the film is derived from that.

    For the Federation to be brought back to an even keel, Marcus' vision of endless war has to be put aside, and Khan has to be contained somehow.  Just to make things for fun, Carol Marcus, the daughter of the Admiral, stows away on the Enterprise.

    So, will the Enterprise crew be up for it?

-----Scores-----

    Cinematography: 7/10 For the most part, the blending of CGI with real photography was well done.  I saw why there are so many posted complaints about lens flare, however.

    Sound: 6/10 The often symphonic music seemed an odd choice, and only amplified my misgivings about the film.

    Acting: 7/10 Good, except for the miscasting of the pivotal character Khan.  I liked the performances of Karl Urban, John Cho, Simon Pegg, Anton Yelchin, Bruce Greenwood, and Peter Weller quite a lot.

    Screenplay: 5/10  Usually, I watch action films in one sitting with no breaks whatsoever.  This property took me four days to watch, since it just did not interest me that much, at any stage.  The three principals all seemed emotionally childish and short of training for their chosen profession. It seemed utterly unlikely that such incompetence could produce good results in very difficult situations.

I enjoyed this move.  However I think that they have missed a number of key parts of the original.  Such as the relationships, good and bad, that made the show what it was.  And the adventures that it took you on.

what a horrible spectacle of special effects and constant, droning action sequences. JJ Abrams has completely lost view on what Star Trek was and what made it resonate so deeply with its fans. epic fail.

J.J. Abrams has brought me back to the Star Trek universe. With this amazing film.

In 2259, the starship USS Enterprise is on a survey mission to the planet Nibiru, studying a primitive culture. Captain James T. Kirk (Chris Pine) and First Officer Spock (Zachary Quinto) attempt to save the planet's inhabitants from a volcanic eruption. When Spock's life is endangered, Kirk violates the Prime Directive in order to save him, exposing the Enterprise to the native inhabitants, a decision with which Spock disagrees. Returning to Earth, Kirk loses command of the Enterprise and Admiral Christopher Pike (Bruce Greenwood) is reinstated as its commanding officer. Pike manages to convince Admiral Marcus to allow Kirk to continue as his first officer on the Enterprise, rather than being sent back to the Academy. Meanwhile, a secret Section 31 installation in London is bombed by a renegade Starfleet officer, Commander John Harrison (Benedict Cumberbatch). During a meeting of Starfleet commanders to discuss the situation, Harrison attacks in a jumpship, killing Pike. Kirk disables the jumpship, but Harrison uses a prototype portable transwarp transporter device to escape to Kronos, the Klingon homeworld, knowing Starfleet would be unable to follow. Fleet Admiral Alexander Marcus (Peter Weller) orders the Enterprise to hunt and kill Harrison, arming them with 72 prototype photon torpedoes, shielded and untraceable to sensors...

Star Trek: Into Darkness, or STID, as the kids are calling it (which makes me sad 'cause it's akin to both STI's and STD's) is, in my unprofessional opinion, a step up from the previous instalment (which I did still quite enjoy). 

Both J.J. Abram's 2009 film, as well as Into Darkness did both, however, seem to have an issue I couldn't overlook in common. And that is that both essentially feel like an incredibly drawn out episode of a TV show. And I've seen next to nothing of the old Star Trek series, so it's not from that sort of a view I've come to have this feeling. It's just a sort of unshakable notion I developed after a few minutes from the start during each film. Even in this aspect, Into Darkness is a slight improvement on its forebear.

This new Star Trek film is, unfortunately, riddled with plot holes. Some... Or at least one, is completely unforgivable. They're not enough to ruin the film per se, but it does make me wonder about Abram's ability to be a showrunner in the future if he can't even handle Star Trek. Right from the get go I had questions that could have easily been answered with only a couple of lines of dialogue's worth of effort. Which was sad, because it cast a pall over what was, at its heart, an enjoyable piece of cinema.

Despite these issues worsening as the movie progressed, a congratulatory word does again have to go out to Abram's and his team for their tweaked timeline. Working a way in which to successfully reboot the franchise, without belittling the integrity of the original was a great move (moreover, they've left themselves open for more deviations in the future, now that the concept is established). Very smart.

Zachary Quinto, Karl Urban, Simon Pegg, John Cho and Anton Yelchin returning is of course a big plus for me. Completely unsurprisingly there just as fantastic as ever. But, that kind of Tumblr user would I be if I didn't give a special bit of praise to Benedict Cumberbatch (which all levity aside, is actually well earned from the Brit, who makes for a spectacular villain).

Major character inconsistencies are permitted for the sake of the action, and, in an attempt to avoid spoilers, I will say this: there is a difference between fan-service homage and blatant rip-off. However, the majority of the movie is still entertaining enough to be enjoyable despite its major final flaws.

 For me, this movie was slightly overpromised. The 'A' Cinemascore, all my FB friends raving about it, and all the positive reviews, I somehow allowed myself to believe it could be even better than the 2009 film. That was an unfair expectation on my part. It is certainly better (by far) than any other Trek film or TV show ever made. The special effects are lights-out amazing, and while a couple new characters have been borrowed, their newer versions are *much* more convincing - in fact (gasp!) - one in particular is much better than the original. 

 But overall, the 2009 film was slightly better, only because it captured the optimism, adventure, and humor at the heart of Roddenberry's series. Into Darkness is an amazing film, but the 2009 movie will always be the standard against which I judge any future Trek product. Still, just like in 2009, anything that can drum up this much mainstream interest in Trek is alright in my book! Into Darkness Grade: A.

Good special effects, good action, but lacking in story and character continuity. This review will contain major SPOILERS, so be warned now.

The movie starts out with Kirk and McCoy running from an alien race after taking a scroll. The reason they are on the planet is the volcano is about to erupt and this will be a global catastrophe. The Enterprise and its crew are suppose to stop the eruption without the indigenous population knowing that other lifeforms exist in the universe. And how do they do this? By hiding the Enterprise under the ocean. This starts out bad. First off, the Prime Directive would prevent them from stopping the volcano because that is a natural occurrence, not man-made. Also, the Enterprise can be in orbit and beam the cold-fusion device into the volcano; they don't have to risk the life of their first officer to do this. Also, Uhura is on the shuttle with Sulu? Why is a Communications Officer on this mission? Nonetheless, Kirk orders the Enterprise to reemerge from the ocean, violating the Prime Directive, and save Spock before he is consumed by the lava. Kirk is summarily ripped of his command. Well, it doesn't start off well but it must get better, right? Unfortunately not. The action and effects are very good, but the core of what made Star Trek great has been lost. Karl Urban was, again, the best at portraying Leonard McCoy; but his screen time was very limited. Bennidict Cumberpatch is always a treat to watch on screen but his John Harrison, who turns out to be Khan Noonian Sing, is vastly different than the Khan Trekkers know from Space Seed and Trek 2. For one, this new Khan is obviously British when Khan is suppose to be Indian, a Sikh. This Khan is a murdering psychopath when the Montalban Khan was a calculating dictator. How could the actions of Nero change the nature of a 21st century eugenics superman? Also, how could the actions of Nero change how Klingons now look and act? In this movie, Klingons have blue eyes, wear masks, and don jewelry. Out of all the series (including the cartoon) and movies, this has never been the case. And when has a starship ever been able to get close to the Klingon homeworld without being attacked by a Bird of Prey? Another problem with the Klingons in this movie is that Praxis, the Klingon moon, has been destroyed. Wait, isn't that suppose to happen much later, at the end of the 23rd century? Another problem is Carol Marcus; in Trek 2, Carol Marcus does not have a British accent but she does in this (because Alice Eve is a Brit). They couldn't have her speak with an American accent?

There are other problems but needless to say, the film is a good action and effects popcorn flick. It is unfortunate that the core of what made Star Trek great has been lost.

For those new to the Trek franchise this rebooted series will please many by offering plenty of action by taking advantage of all the latest special effects Hollywood has to offer.  But for those 1st and 2nd gen trekkies perhaps one important feature is missing one key ingredient one would expect from a series based upon a future vision:  most it's elements it's still stuck in Gene Roddenberry's 1970's version of the future.  Adding younger actors, new lines and whooshing warp effects doesn't do much to make you feel like you're seeing or experiencing anything all that new.  As the late great Roger Ebert once said so eloquently, Star Trek "was kind of terrific once", but one would expect more (and new) creative vision from one of the largest sci fi franchises that has spanned decades.  The recycled and predictable plots of saving the universe with sparks, fading shields and neck pinches is running out of gas and a poor vision of the future past the 21st century and lack of "bold" creative vision that inspired many in the prime time hours of the early 1970s.

Not quite as impressive as the first movie, but still quite a fun thrill ride. This is the best of what blockbuster has to offer. JJ Abrams is also a pop culture geek who throws in nods to the past (almost the whole movie in some ways is a love letter to the Original Series' greatest bad guy) as well as having things that look exactly like Star Wars (the Starfleet dress uniforms look somewhat like Empire uniforms on the Death Star; a shuttlecraft making like the Millennium Falcon and going sideways through a tight squeeze). This works since I swear Abrams is one day going to make Return of the Star Trek Jedi Klingon, and combine both universes into the biggest Sci-Fi Nerdgasm of all time (and the Internet will explode). There's still room for more of the crew though, Kirk and Spock get plenty, Uhura gets more than enough, happily Simon Pegg's Scotty gets a bigger role this time, but I would have loved more Karl Urban as Bones, because he's just so good. Here's hoping enough other people feel the same way. Frankly Chekov is almost a joke in these films, and Sulu is a solid presence but has the right amount of screen time.

Star Trek Into Darkness(2013)
Directed By: J.J.Abrams
Starring: Chris Pine(James T. Kirk), Zachery Quinto(Mr.Spock), Zoe Saladna(Uhura), Simon Pegg(Scotty), John Chu(Sulu), Alice Eve(Carol Marcus),and Benedict Cummberbatch(John Harrison)
My Review
My history with the Star Trek franchise is very little, I have only seen a few episodes of Star Trek:The Next Generation, watched Wrath of Khan and the Star Trek reboot from 2009. Although my mother has been with this franchise since the beginning. She watched the very first show, The next Generation and watched all the movies.
I guess your thinking my mother dragged me to see this with her but she didn't I wanted to go see this film but not because I love Star Trek. I wanted to see this film because the villain looked threatening and sounded awesome. The villain in the first Star Trek film to me wasn't memorable but to me the one this film was way more memorable and the first film didn't do this, they didn't have their characters of Starship Enterprise explore new worlds like they did in the show.
The film revolves around captain James T. Kirk who doesn't follow the guidelines of Starfleet and is assigned to go downward from captian to first officer. Until a man named John Harrison attacks the commanders of Starfleet and becomes a fugitive. Kirk must prove he is a worthy captain by leading his crew to a manhunt to a war zone world to capture him.
The actors do a great job at portraying their characters and I honestly do believe this sequel is better then the first film that for some reason alot of people like and have even heard that the previous film is better then this one even though as I said that the villain is unmemorable and they don't capture the essence of Starfleets mission which is too seek out new worlds and to boldly go where no man has gone before. The special effects are better then any other of the Star Trek adaptations of course and it is a better and greater thrill ride I give this Star Trek film a 5 out of 5 I think some Star Trek fans will love it while others may not apparently.

Honestly, for all the hype I've heard ("Watch the highest-rated film of 2013!" etc., etc.), this film was not only horribly overrated, it's not even close to the first film in terms of quality.  The effects and action are great, but the story, which starts off promisingly, gets confusing and boring as hell quickly.  There's also no payoff to all the problems that the Enterprise's crew goes through.  In the end, there's no real punishment for Khan, so what the hell was the point of all this?  He killed thousands of people and got away with it.  Yeah, he's in hibernation indefinitely, but it's only a matter of time until somebody sets him free I'm sure...perhaps for a sequel sometime down the line.  I have no idea why people seem to love this movie so much...there's really nothing special about it.  Movies like this are why I don't trust the majority's opinion on movies...

Also the whole idiotic notion that the Federation is purely non-military is complete bunk. The UFP is a combination of research, political, and military defensive interests, hence the firepower provided in its ships. I sort of loved Star Trek: Into Darkness. J.J. Abrams is a crazily gifted individual that has that rare virtue of raising any material by the sheer force of his fantastic eye and attention to details. I cannot stress how much I appreciate that he never seems to cut corners production-wise, you can always see, and hear, every penny invested on his films put to good use. He also has a really underrated ability with actors, creating tightly woven ensembles that bounce off each other well. That said, he desperately (!) needs better writers. His tendency to work with middling scripts is far too frequent and worrisome; I wonder how far he could go without such a huge obstacle right from the beginning. Now that he's directing that little movie called Star Wars VII he should do something about it, his life (or at least sanity) depends on it.

Some other random thoughts: 1. Simon Pegg is THE shit. Earned comic relief in this post Marvel movie's landscape is practically unheard of, and to me he always delivers the goods. Effortlessly. 2. Giacchino's "Enterprising Young Men" still gives me hardcore chills. I refuse to believe that it will ever grow old, and I would pay serious money to hear it performed live with a full orchestra. 3. I'm getting used to this 3D stuff, which kind of boggles my mind. You just can't refuse all that gloriously sharp eye candy coming off the screen, especially when rendered in such beautiful color schemes. Yeah, Abrams is good with that too.

Full of holes. As far as I'm concerned its a failure. It seems to have two purposes: 1) To try to change the target audience from people that love Star Trek to mindless adolescents who don't know much about it. I.e. to try to make it cool and have lots of mindless running around. And 2) To give something to existing fans with nostalgic bits from the past, including riding on the back of Wrath of Khan. It fails in the latter, thats why its a failure, and it ruins the work of the last film. It made money, but anyone that like Star Trek would have paid to see it just because its Star Trek and because the last film was so good. It may have succeeded in gaining their new audience, I don't know, but to me that just means that any future films will be no better than made for TV 'Baywatch'. The film is full of holes and stupidity. For example, the super-genius Khan's brilliant plan to free his people is to load them into missiles. Missiles that he knows will be fired at a planet. Nowhere in the film is indicated how he intends to remove those people before the missiles actually hit the ground. Is this how one rescues a person? Not to mention all the different processing that will happen to the missiles by strangers before they actually get fired - they are after all, an extra special military weapon. The military does not tend to just leave such things in a back warehouse with no testing and monitoring. This stuff annoyed me to no end, but add to that the mindless running around, e.g. Kirk running around the big ship and the silly jumping between ships through space. If this wasn't enough, there is the needless, cloyingly bad nostalgic looking back, e.g. the famous Spock dying of radiation scene. The people that saw the original scene will still remember it and didn't need to see an inferior version repeated. Those that never saw it before were not going to be impressed with it in this film, it was just boring as there isn't the great emotional bond between Spock and Kirk here. In addition, if you're trying to sell to people that like mindless running around and jumping between flying boats, what's the point of this scene? I went in there knowing nothing of the story, I didn't know it was based around Khan, else I may not have watched it. Wrath of Khan was a great film, a classic. They should have left it alone. They obviously ran out of ideas for the follow up to the last film. A big big let down on such great promise. I wish I hadn't seen it. Abrams is good but he is much over-hyped - something that screw up that talent (in the short term anyway). The new Star Wars could be either great or rubbish.

This movie blew.  Anyone who thinks otherwise is not a true trek fan.  First 5 minutes is ridiculous.  Let's drop Spock into a volcano with an explosive.  5 minutes later they are beaming him out when the cable breaks (while breaking the prime directive).  Why not just beam the explosive in to begin with?  Khan...He was a tactical genious super soldier.  He was not a "how to build a bigger starship in black" person.  Bigger starship, less crew = stupid.  Much harder to run 2 miles to fix something than 2 feet.  Oh...and let's not forget, if you want to show something is "Evil" paint it "black".  Then we get to the most idiotic aspect of this movie.  Teleportation to the Klingon homeworld.  That's a four day trip.  Two hundred years later they still couldn't teleport someone to the moon.  But somehow, using 200+ year old knowledge and technology they manage to come up with a solution?  Can't believe people actually liked this thing.  If it's CGI and poor storytelling you want, this one is the movie for you.

As somewhat of a Trekkie, I have to admit that Abrams' new films are disappointing. They have a lot of great action, good casting, and even all of the nonsensical tech of the old films. Not to mention plenty of references and fan service. 

But I have come to realize that those things were never what I found appealing about Star Trek; they're petty affectations. Without the character development and grand sci-fi concepts of the previous Trek universe, this film is just a heartless, soulless husk wearing a Federation uniform. 

Star Trek was never about huge action scenes or dazzling special effects. I mean half of the decisions they made during the series were to save on their budgets. But because of that, the previous series and movies had more room to breathe and engage the mind. It had to be written almost like a stage play because they couldn't afford to have too many set changes or massive battle scenes. Going from that to this is like trying to remake Twelve Angry Men as an action thriller.

All of that characterization and exploration of concepts is now awash in a sea of lens flare. This film, much more than the first, is an extremely predictable blockbuster title with really nothing to say. Is that certain bad guy going to get back up in a 'he's not quite dead' moment? Of course he is. Is that certain hero going to be resurrected after making a tragic sacrifice? Well, this being summer popcorn fare, they wouldn't want to leave on even a bittersweet note now would they? There are so many cliche moments in this film that it seems more like a pastiche of overdone action moments from the past 30 years than it does an original effort. You can call everything that's going to happen, which is extremely deflating.

If there is another Star Trek film in the rebooted series, I really hope Abrams takes time to slow down and smell the alien roses. I also hope I'm not alone in not needing constant, migraine inducing action in order to stay interested. Give Star Trek a little space, and some room to breathe and find its humanity, and it can do great things. Otherwise, it just isn't anything special.

For J.J. Abrams second outing into the Star Trek universe, I found Star Trek Into Darkness to be only a little more well thought out than its predecessor.  The story picks up some months after the events of Star Trek and the crew of the Enterprise is taking part to assist in saving a primitive alien race from total annihilation.  As part of the action, Kirk must decide to risk exposing themselves in an effort to save Spock, thus breaking the Prime Directive.  It then follows on down a path of sedition in Starfleet after a rogue agent causes a bombing in London and attacks Starfleet brass in San Francisco.  We find out said agent is in fact Khan, the same character introduced in the original series and film, The Wrath of Khan.  
Now that you know the general gist of the story, let me tell you why I really don't like it.  I'm a hardcore Trekkie, yes, but I'm also someone with a fairly open mind about Star Trek.  I like new ideas and I like how a new spin can breathe life into an aging franchise.  However, this movie is only marginally better at telling a great Star Trek story than its predecessor.  Does it have lots of sexy action and a whole new shiny look to it? Yes, but it also tries to be intentionally better than that which came before it.  The flashy looks and action isn't all that necessary if you have a good story.  Star Trek Into Darkness doesn't have that; in fact it is literally regurgitating another story already told in this mythos.  I will say that I liked this movie more than the last one, but J.J. Abrams has a lot learn if he is going to keep the legions of fans coming back for more.  I can only imagine what it will spell for Star Wars: Episode VII.

Abbram's new vision of the long running Sci fi franchise may not please the most hardcore fans but never the less Star Trek Into Darkness brings plenty of  entertainment and thrilling action. 

The Starship Enterprise must capture a terrorist after he blows a strike on Section 31 on Earth. They find out he is located on the planet Kronos but must take great caution to avoid starting a war with the Klingons. Kirk and Spock's friendship is strained as Spock is trying balance his out right honesty and loyalty towards the captain. 

Benedict Cumberbatch, best known for his leading role in successful BBC series Sherlock steals the show with a outstanding performance as Harrison. Once more Chris Pine (Kirk) and Zachary Quinto (Spock) played great off each other, providing the comedy while giving true portrayals of their character. Alice Eve is brought in to play scientist, Dr Carole Wallace. It seems like a clear attempt to bring in a female hero but for the most part is one dimensional. 

The films predecessor was clearly used to set up the character but little is done to progress those characters. Despite these flaws 'Into Darkness' is still a fantastic addition and a fun action packed film. It brings potential and promise to the third instalment set for a 2016 release.

Space: The final frontier. Or is it?

J.J. Abrams delivers another sci-fi roller coaster ride to kick off the summer season with Star Trek Into Darkness. Following in the success of the 2009 hit, the much-anticipated sequel follows Jim Kirk (Chris Pine), Spock (Zachary Quinto) and his ragtag crew aboard the USS Enterprise. 

The film is as fun, fast and furiously entertaining as it's predecessor. And that ends up being the best word to describe Into Darkness: Entertaining. From start to finish it's an explosive thrill ride moving from one flare-riddeled action scene to the next. Perfectly blended with a impeccably-paced story and an excellent cast, especially Benedict Cumberbatch (playing the menacing villain), it rolls along at a blistering pace rarely stopping to let you take in the eye-popping effects or gorgeous sets.

After Oblivion and now this, I can easily say this year will most definitely be remembered as one of the best science fiction years for cinema in a very, VERY long time. And guess what? The years not even half way finished and the summer season has just begun. So buckle up your seat-belts, turn your phasers to stun and prepare to beam yourself up!

Where to even start? Okay, let me start by first saying that Benedict Cumberbatch's performance as Khan was a very good one. He was cold hearted, deceiving looking, and hell-bent on finding destruction. There were some great action scenes in this movies, particularly the one where Khan and Kirk are flying through space in advanced "jumpsuits." Dialogue did not seem to be a problem for the people who formulated the script (Alex Kurtzman, Damon Lindelof, and Roberto Orci) as it was always witty and sharp. Zachary Quinto, again reprised his role as Spock, and did a decently fine job at that. He is convincing more and more lately, that he can pretty much act in anything. Star Trek: Into Darkness has some very intense scenes that are emotional, subtle, and destructive. This space opera is done with diligent pacing, and some of the finest use of special effects I've seen in a while. J.J. Abrams is taking directing to a whole new level with a nearly flawless movie. My only complaint would be that the camera scenes were beginning to resemble what Michael Bay does in his movies. SHAKY. I swear, Michael Bay has terrets. Anyways, the movie leans more so on the emotional side than one would've expected. What's different between the beloved franchises of Star Wars and Star Trek, is the Star Trek has a director that's made two movies in a row that have been brilliant with an emotional tear drop or two. Yes, Star Wars Episodes VII-XV got the J.J. Abrams treatment as well, but we have no idea what's going to become of them (there are rumors swirling around the Benedict Cumberbatch has a role!) yet. So, lets rewind to the Episodes I-III. Does anyone actually remember a good, emotional scene in those movies? Neither do I. To say that George Lucas can't write a love scene, or an emotional scene, is to say that facebook is just a website. A complete understatement. So, drawing parallels with the Star Trek universe and the Star Wars universe should be easier unless J.J. Abrams botches things up with Episode VII like George Lucas did with Episodes I and II. On an earlier note, however, this movie has got the goods. Go watch it. There is never a dull scene with any of these actors/actresses, and the director gives it his all with a non cliched movie with even a little touch of humor.

A much better interpretation of the classic franchise that Abrams last attempt.  The Kirk character seems to fill out his Star Fleet uniform much better.  Although the film is filled with obvious gags and transpositions of old Star Trek lore they are executed just about right so that you are not constantly groaning from their presence.  The action is about right and not over the top as in so many Hollywood projects these days and the writing seems to actually go someplace most of the time.  All in all an enjoyable installment.  (I would personally still take The Wrath of Khan over all the other films in this family though.)

Really entertaining but it drives me nuts how Spock always tells Kirk how impossible a feat is, and then they accomplish the feat.  It makes me feel like the writers think the audience is stupid.
